data.author: WindInTheWillows
data.content: Scottgekko There have been a number of placings at ever decreasing prices, the last one overwhelmingly supported by insties that have been present since the first round at IPO.  5p was a floor.  There has been a seller over the last 4-6 weeks or more that has shifted somewhere in the region of 10-15m shares or thereabouts in my estimation.  This was likely to clear their 5p stock exposure and hold onto warrants.  Those sales appear to have dried up, which means one of two (broadly) things 1. The seller is cleared out, hence now remaining 5p placees averaging down are now holding their stock for better gains (last placing at 16p) 2. The large seller does not want to sell more stock yet and is holding for news. The result is bid pressure that has forced the price up.  I would say the news has been (very) positive the last few weeks, but if there was a lot of stock being actively dumped or an oversupply we wouldn't have gained 60% in short order.  Occams razor - stock has dried up sufficiently for the MMs to raise the bar. Its edged further up today, further proving my point. Seller not being tempted easily or out of ammo. 🤷 Your alternative opinion is welcome.  Whats your view?

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: Well I wasn't imagining we would have quite the range of projections that I read here today.  Had I be around I might have suggested that 35p was a little on the pessimistic side for something approaching fair value but it might not be a poor guess at where we could be over the coming months and a 4x return in 12 months is nothing to be sniffed at. But "fair value" is another matter which hopefully would come more clearly into view as the PFS and other details are established. I had in mind something in three figures - ranging from 130-175p - for an early stage mining development but with natural step-ups as the development progresses to FID and construction.  I've based this on what I would hope were fairly conservative assumptions for financing terms but however you look at it, it tells me people invested here will want to take slices of profits rather than make a clean break when they hit their target - there is too much to lose by cutting and running. It's fine to take profits but I would advise taking a slice here and there while the market is in this mood and leaving the rest to go on for better things. Of course if we do reach a £7bn+ market cap, I might feel obliged to give a large share of my second £m to good causes.

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: They are much further than that from production.  Earliest we will see anything meaningful is 2029 and 2030 is what Ignacio is putting out there. The sequencing is CEOL fast track -> PFS -> Partnering/Financing -> FID -> Construction -> Production but within this is an Environmental Assessment which will take up to 2.5 years. That's not to say we won't see the SP ramp up significantly over that period.  Suppose we were producing 20kt per annum in 2030. At current lithium prices that's around $350m of revenue per annum which is clearly not in the current SP.  That discount will unwind with successive steps toward production.

data.author: Gorblimey
data.content: Https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/lithium "Lithium carbonate futures in China soared past CNY 138,000 per tonne in January, the highest in over two years, as strong demand magnified the outlook of capped supply. Ambitious bets in power and datacenter infrastructure by the Chinese government was combined with the announcement of higher power storage spending, supporting the outlook for lithium and other battery metals. This was combined with Beijing stating it would double EV charging capacity to 180 gigawatts by 2027, supporting lithium-rich energy storage systems. Besides domestic expenditure, foreign storage system sales from Chinese companies rose to $66 billion in the first 10 months of the year, overtaking $54 billion from electric vehicle exports. Meanwhile, authorities stated 27 mining permits were canceled in the lithium hub of Jiangxi, aligned with the earlier suspension of activity in CATL's Jianxiawo lithium mine amid Beijing's anti-involution campaign."

data.author: ICB888
data.content: From the recent RNS: “ Ignacio Mehech, Chief Executive Officer of CleanTech Lithium, commented: "We believe we are the only applicant eligible to apply for the CEOL at Laguna Verde under the Ministry's streamlined process. We hold well over the 80% of the mining concessions in the CEOL polygon required by the Ministry, we have formed a consortium with a financially strong partner, and we bring extensive experience in the mining and lithium extraction industry, both in Chile and globally. Our application has been submitted a month before the deadline, and we can expect to the hear back from the Government in February 2026, if not before. This is a pivotal moment in CleanTech Lithium's pathway to developing a high-quality lithium project at Laguna Verde. "By forming a consortium, ASL is supported in its CEOL application by the Partner which will enable CTL to comfortably meet the financial capability criteria set by the Ministry of Mining. We are very grateful for the support of the Partner under commercial arrangements agreeable to both parties.” If you also listen to the Investor Meet presentation you will be in little doubt that the CEO is as certain as anyone can be that the CEOL is in the bag.

data.author: Gorblimey
data.content: Https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/lithium "Lithium carbonate futures surged past CNY 150,000 per tonne in January, gaining nearly 30% since the start of the year to a two-year high, as signs of strong demand for power storage coincided with the outlook of capped supply. Chinese authorities lowered export rebates for battery producers from April, driving manufacturers to front-run lithium orders. In the meantime, ambitious bets in power and datacenter infrastructure by the Chinese government was combined with the announcement of higher power storage spending, supporting the outlook for lithium and other battery metals. This was combined with Beijing stating it would double EV charging capacity to 180 gigawatts by 2027, supporting lithium-rich energy storage systems. This reflects exponential uptake in e-trucks, buses and BESS — sectors often underweighted in consensus models. Investor takeaway: If this longer-term demand trajectory materializes, the bull market in lithium would be driven by structural electrification trends — not just short-term price swings. 📈 Why This Matters for Shareholders of Cleantech Lithium Companies 📌 He called the current rally right Lee’s forecasts in March 2025 anticipated a renewed price and demand upswing long before many analysts pivoted bullish, and the market has since followed that trajectory. data.author: Crocqman
data.content: Lord, some large holders may release a statement when they have finished their trading activity to alert the market, perhaps to confirm they are still actively support the company and give reasons for their change in strategy if they have been selling, or to confirm there is no intention to make a bid, or put pressure on a company if they have been buying. Or for any other reason They could be selling down for tax reasons, to raise cash for other requirements, etc but still be a long term holder and supporter. The trading activity may go against their perceived stance, so they may want to clarify the change. Uncertainty if a large holde starts selling may lead others to start selling and generate panic when there is a logical explanation. It is not a requirement, and not done frequently, but it does happen

data.author: Crocqman
data.content: Hermit, in short, no. It has always been a best efforts basis for reporting the direction on sites like this based on mid price, volume, time, etc which is why it can often be 'reported' incorrectly . The direction of a trade (buy/sell) is never reported to market at the time of execution, there is just an obligation to report to the official regulator by T+1 in a separate transaction report, usually sent after hours that trading day, but before 12pm the next day. The regulator doesn't publish this information to my knowledge other than when we see things like TR1 notifications, or open short positions which are reported to the regulator via different methods. Ironically, the reasons for all this uncertainty with the direction of trades is part of mifid II regulations ( trade reporting and transaction reporting) that were brought in back in 2018 to make this more 'transparent'.

data.author: Gorblimey
data.content: Https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/lithium Lithium carbonate futures surged past [resistance] CNY 170,000 per tonne in January, gaining nearly 30% since the start of the year to a two-year high, as signs of strong demand for power storage coincided with the outlook of capped supply. Chinese authorities lowered export rebates for battery producers from April, driving manufacturers to front-run lithium orders. In the meantime, ambitious bets in power and datacenter infrastructure by the Chinese government was combined with the announcement of higher power storage spending, supporting the outlook for lithium and other battery metals. This was combined with Beijing stating it would double EV charging capacity to 180 gigawatts by 2027, supporting lithium-rich energy storage systems. Meanwhile, authorities stated 27 mining permits were cancelled in the lithium hub of Jiangxi, aligned with the earlier suspension of activity in CATL's Jianxiawo lithium mine amid Beijing's anti-involution campaign.

data.author: Gorblimey
data.content: Https://www.mining.com/us-proposed-secure-act-aims-to-offset-chinas-grip-on-critical-minerals/ US lawmakers last week introduced bipartisan legislation to create a new authority for a $2.5 billion critical minerals stockpile, aiming to counter China’s dominance of global supply chains. The proposed Securing Essential and Critical US Resources and Elements (SECURE) Minerals Act would establish a Strategic Resilience Reserve (SRR) to support domestic production and processing of minerals vital to electrification, clean energy and national defense. China currently controls over 60% of the world’s mined rare earths and about 90% of their processing. The Asian nation also holds a major share of the refined production of lithium, graphite and cobalt, all minerals key to electrification, clean energy and national defense. For lithium, China has created a huge glut that has driven down prices globally, rendering many projects in the West unprofitable. In the rare earth sector, it deployed export curbs that have also resulted in high prices. US Senators Jeanne Shaheen (D-NH) and Todd Young (R-IN), alongside Representatives Rob Wittman (R-VA-01) and John Moolenaar (R-MI-02), introduced new legislation to support domestic supply chains to meet national and economic security needs through the creation of a new SRR. The legislation has been introduced on a bicameral and bipartisan basis, reflecting early alignment across chambers and parties. Critical minerals have emerged as a key chokepoint in the global economy, the lawmakers said. The SECURE Act would establish the SRR in an independent government corporation, run by a seven-member board appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate. “China’s global dominance of critical minerals supply chains gives it significant leverage and leaves the US vulnerable to economic coercion. This bipartisan legislation is a historic investment in making the US economy more resilient and supporting good-paying jobs in key sectors like aerospace, autos and technology,” Senator Shaheen said in a news release. “Delivering much-needed stability to the market, providing targeted investments and stockpiling key inputs will help insulate the US from foreign threats and will provide a significant, and cost effective, boost to the US economy.” Path to law Sahar Hafeez, senior counsel, international trade and national security matters at Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman’s Washington DC office told MINING.COM such legislation takes time and will involve subsequent edits and versions on the path to being passed into law. “We understand that the House Committee on Natural Resources is looking to schedule a mark-up and that the Senate is aiming for including this as part of the NDAA (US National Defense Authorization Act),” Hafeez said in an email. The bill establishes new statutory authority to create a $2.5 billion strategic reserve, rather than relying on pre-existing

data.content: Https://www.mining.com/us-proposed-secure-act-aims-to-offset-chinas-grip-on-critical-minerals/ US lawmakers last week introduced bipartisan legislation to create a new authority for a $2.5 billion critical minerals stockpile, aiming to counter China’s dominance of global supply chains. The proposed Securing Essential and Critical US Resources and Elements (SECURE) Minerals Act would establish a Strategic Resilience Reserve (SRR) to support domestic production and processing of minerals vital to electrification, clean energy and national defense. China currently controls over 60% of the world’s mined rare earths and about 90% of their processing. The Asian nation also holds a major share of the refined production of lithium, graphite and cobalt, all minerals key to electrification, clean energy and national defense. For lithium, China has created a huge glut that has driven down prices globally, rendering many projects in the West unprofitable. In the rare earth sector, it deployed export curbs that have also resulted in high prices. US Senators Jeanne Shaheen (D-NH) and Todd Young (R-IN), alongside Representatives Rob Wittman (R-VA-01) and John Moolenaar (R-MI-02), introduced new legislation to support domestic supply chains to meet national and economic security needs through the creation of a new SRR. The legislation has been introduced on a bicameral and bipartisan basis, reflecting early alignment across chambers and parties. Critical minerals have emerged as a key chokepoint in the global economy, the lawmakers said. The SECURE Act would establish the SRR in an independent government corporation, run by a seven-member board appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate. “China’s global dominance of critical minerals supply chains gives it significant leverage and leaves the US vulnerable to economic coercion. This bipartisan legislation is a historic investment in making the US economy more resilient and supporting good-paying jobs in key sectors like aerospace, autos and technology,” Senator Shaheen said in a news release. “Delivering much-needed stability to the market, providing targeted investments and stockpiling key inputs will help insulate the US from foreign threats and will provide a significant, and cost effective, boost to the US economy.” Path to law Sahar Hafeez, senior counsel, international trade and national security matters at Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman’s Washington DC office told MINING.COM such legislation takes time and will involve subsequent edits and versions on the path to being passed into law. “We understand that the House Committee on Natural Resources is looking to schedule a mark-up and that the Senate is aiming for including this as part of the NDAA (US National Defense Authorization Act),” Hafeez said in an email. The bill establishes new statutory authority to create a $2.5 billion strategic reserve, rather than relying on pre-existing

data.author: Crocqman
data.content: Lord, some large holders may release a statement when they have finished their trading activity to alert the market, perhaps to confirm they are still actively support the company and give reasons for their change in strategy if they have been selling, or to confirm there is no intention to make a bid, or put pressure on a company if they have been buying. Or for any other reason They could be selling down for tax reasons, to raise cash for other requirements, etc but still be a long term holder and supporter. The trading activity may go against their perceived stance, so they may want to clarify the change. Uncertainty if a large holde starts selling may lead others to start selling and generate panic when there is a logical explanation. It is not a requirement, and not done frequently, but it does happen

data.author: Crocqman
data.content: Hermit, in short, no. It has always been a best efforts basis for reporting the direction on sites like this based on mid price, volume, time, etc which is why it can often be 'reported' incorrectly . The direction of a trade (buy/sell) is never reported to market at the time of execution, there is just an obligation to report to the official regulator by T+1 in a separate transaction report, usually sent after hours that trading day, but before 12pm the next day. The regulator doesn't publish this information to my knowledge other than when we see things like TR1 notifications, or open short positions which are reported to the regulator via different methods. Ironically, the reasons for all this uncertainty with the direction of trades is part of mifid II regulations ( trade reporting and transaction reporting) that were brought in back in 2018 to make this more 'transparent'.

data.content: Https://www.mining.com/us-proposed-secure-act-aims-to-offset-chinas-grip-on-critical-minerals/ US lawmakers last week introduced bipartisan legislation to create a new authority for a $2.5 billion critical minerals stockpile, aiming to counter China’s dominance of global supply chains. The proposed Securing Essential and Critical US Resources and Elements (SECURE) Minerals Act would establish a Strategic Resilience Reserve (SRR) to support domestic production and processing of minerals vital to electrification, clean energy and national defense. China currently controls over 60% of the world’s mined rare earths and about 90% of their processing. The Asian nation also holds a major share of the refined production of lithium, graphite and cobalt, all minerals key to electrification, clean energy and national defense. For lithium, China has created a huge glut that has driven down prices globally, rendering many projects in the West unprofitable. In the rare earth sector, it deployed export curbs that have also resulted in high prices. US Senators Jeanne Shaheen (D-NH) and Todd Young (R-IN), alongside Representatives Rob Wittman (R-VA-01) and John Moolenaar (R-MI-02), introduced new legislation to support domestic supply chains to meet national and economic security needs through the creation of a new SRR. The legislation has been introduced on a bicameral and bipartisan basis, reflecting early alignment across chambers and parties. Critical minerals have emerged as a key chokepoint in the global economy, the lawmakers said. The SECURE Act would establish the SRR in an independent government corporation, run by a seven-member board appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate. “China’s global dominance of critical minerals supply chains gives it significant leverage and leaves the US vulnerable to economic coercion. This bipartisan legislation is a historic investment in making the US economy more resilient and supporting good-paying jobs in key sectors like aerospace, autos and technology,” Senator Shaheen said in a news release. “Delivering much-needed stability to the market, providing targeted investments and stockpiling key inputs will help insulate the US from foreign threats and will provide a significant, and cost effective, boost to the US economy.” Path to law Sahar Hafeez, senior counsel, international trade and national security matters at Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman’s Washington DC office told MINING.COM such legislation takes time and will involve subsequent edits and versions on the path to being passed into law. “We understand that the House Committee on Natural Resources is looking to schedule a mark-up and that the Senate is aiming for including this as part of the NDAA (US National Defense Authorization Act),” Hafeez said in an email. data.author: Crocqman
data.content: Lord, some large holders may release a statement when they have finished their trading activity to alert the market, perhaps to confirm they are still actively support the company and give reasons for their change in strategy if they have been selling, or to confirm there is no intention to make a bid, or put pressure on a company if they have been buying. Or for any other reason They could be selling down for tax reasons, to raise cash for other requirements, etc but still be a long term holder and supporter. The trading activity may go against their perceived stance, so they may want to clarify the change. Uncertainty if a large holde starts selling may lead others to start selling and generate panic when there is a logical explanation. It is not a requirement, and not done frequently, but it does happen

data.author: Crocqman
data.content: Hermit, in short, no. It has always been a best efforts basis for reporting the direction on sites like this based on mid price, volume, time, etc which is why it can often be 'reported' incorrectly . The direction of a trade (buy/sell) is never reported to market at the time of execution, there is just an obligation to report to the official regulator by T+1 in a separate transaction report, usually sent after hours that trading day, but before 12pm the next day. The regulator doesn't publish this information to my knowledge other than when we see things like TR1 notifications, or open short positions which are reported to the regulator via different methods. Ironically, the reasons for all this uncertainty with the direction of trades is part of mifid II regulations ( trade reporting and transaction reporting) that were brought in back in 2018 to make this more 'transparent'.

data.author: Gorblimey
data.content: Https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/lithium Lithium carbonate futures surged past [resistance] CNY 170,000 per tonne in January, gaining nearly 30% since the start of the year to a two-year high, as signs of strong demand for power storage coincided with the outlook of capped supply. Chinese authorities lowered export rebates for battery producers from April, driving manufacturers to front-run lithium orders. In the meantime, ambitious bets in power and datacenter infrastructure by the Chinese government was combined with the announcement of higher power storage spending, supporting the outlook for lithium and other battery metals. This was combined with Beijing stating it would double EV charging capacity to 180 gigawatts by 2027, supporting lithium-rich energy storage systems. Meanwhile, authorities stated 27 mining permits were cancelled in the lithium hub of Jiangxi, aligned with the earlier suspension of activity in CATL's Jianxiawo lithium mine amid Beijing's anti-involution campaign.

data.author: Crocqman
data.content: Lord, some large holders may release a statement when they have finished their trading activity to alert the market, perhaps to confirm they are still actively support the company and give reasons for their change in strategy if they have been selling, or to confirm there is no intention to make a bid, or put pressure on a company if they have been buying. Or for any other reason They could be selling down for tax reasons, to raise cash for other requirements, etc but still be a long term holder and supporter. The trading activity may go against their perceived stance, so they may want to clarify the change. Uncertainty if a large holde starts selling may lead others to start selling and generate panic when there is a logical explanation. It is not a requirement, and not done frequently, but it does happen

data.author: Crocqman
data.content: Hermit, in short, no. It has always been a best efforts basis for reporting the direction on sites like this based on mid price, volume, time, etc which is why it can often be 'reported' incorrectly . The direction of a trade (buy/sell) is never reported to market at the time of execution, there is just an obligation to report to the official regulator by T+1 in a separate transaction report, usually sent after hours that trading day, but before 12pm the next day. The regulator doesn't publish this information to my knowledge other than when we see things like TR1 notifications, or open short positions which are reported to the regulator via different methods. Ironically, the reasons for all this uncertainty with the direction of trades is part of mifid II regulations ( trade reporting and transaction reporting) that were brought in back in 2018 to make this more 'transparent'.

data.author: Gorblimey
data.content: Https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/lithium Lithium carbonate futures surged past [resistance] CNY 170,000 per tonne in January, gaining nearly 30% since the start of the year to a two-year high, as signs of strong demand for power storage coincided with the outlook of capped supply. Chinese authorities lowered export rebates for battery producers from April, driving manufacturers to front-run lithium orders. In the meantime, ambitious bets in power and datacenter infrastructure by the Chinese government was combined with the announcement of higher power storage spending, supporting the outlook for lithium and other battery metals. This was combined with Beijing stating it would double EV charging capacity to 180 gigawatts by 2027, supporting lithium-rich energy storage systems. Meanwhile, authorities stated 27 mining permits were cancelled in the lithium hub of Jiangxi, aligned with the earlier suspension of activity in CATL's Jianxiawo lithium mine amid Beijing's anti-involution campaign.

data.content: Https://www.mining.com/us-proposed-secure-act-aims-to-offset-chinas-grip-on-critical-minerals/ US lawmakers last week introduced bipartisan legislation to create a new authority for a $2.5 billion critical minerals stockpile, aiming to counter China’s dominance of global supply chains. The proposed Securing Essential and Critical US Resources and Elements (SECURE) Minerals Act would establish a Strategic Resilience Reserve (SRR) to support domestic production and processing of minerals vital to electrification, clean energy and national defense. China currently controls over 60% of the world’s mined rare earths and about 90% of their processing. The Asian nation also holds a major share of the refined production of lithium, graphite and cobalt, all minerals key to electrification, clean energy and national defense. For lithium, China has created a huge glut that has driven down prices globally, rendering many projects in the West unprofitable. In the rare earth sector, it deployed export curbs that have also resulted in high prices. US Senators Jeanne Shaheen (D-NH) and Todd Young (R-IN), alongside Representatives Rob Wittman (R-VA-01) and John Moolenaar (R-MI-02), introduced new legislation to support domestic supply chains to meet national and economic security needs through the creation of a new SRR. The legislation has been introduced on a bicameral and bipartisan basis, reflecting early alignment across chambers and parties. Critical minerals have emerged as a key chokepoint in the global economy, the lawmakers said. The SECURE Act would establish the SRR in an independent government corporation, run by a seven-member board appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate. “China’s global dominance of critical minerals supply chains gives it significant leverage and leaves the US vulnerable to economic coercion. This bipartisan legislation is a historic investment in making the US economy more resilient and supporting good-paying jobs in key sectors like aerospace, autos and technology,” Senator Shaheen said in a news release. “Delivering much-needed stability to the market, providing targeted investments and stockpiling key inputs will help insulate the US from foreign threats and will provide a significant, and cost effective, boost to the US economy.” Path to law Sahar Hafeez, senior counsel, international trade and national security matters at Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman’s Washington DC office told MINING.COM such legislation takes time and will involve subsequent edits and versions on the path to being passed into law. “We understand that the House Committee on Natural Resources is looking to schedule a mark-up and that the Senate is aiming for including this as part of the NDAA (US National Defense Authorization Act),” Hafeez said in an email. The bill establishes new statutory authority to create a $2.5 billion strategic reserve, rather than relying on pre-existing

data.author: Crocqman
data.content: Lord, some large holders may release a statement when they have finished their trading activity to alert the market, perhaps to confirm they are still actively support the company and give reasons for their change in strategy if they have been selling, or to confirm there is no intention to make a bid, or put pressure on a company if they have been buying. Or for any other reason They could be selling down for tax reasons, to raise cash for other requirements, etc but still be a long term holder and supporter. The trading activity may go against their perceived stance, so they may want to clarify the change. Uncertainty if a large holde starts selling may lead others to start selling and generate panic when there is a logical explanation. It is not a requirement, and not done frequently, but it does happen

data.author: Crocqman
data.content: Hermit, in short, no. It has always been a best efforts basis for reporting the direction on sites like this based on mid price, volume, time, etc which is why it can often be 'reported' incorrectly . The direction of a trade (buy/sell) is never reported to market at the time of execution, there is just an obligation to report to the official regulator by T+1 in a separate transaction report, usually sent after hours that trading day, but before 12pm the next day. The regulator doesn't publish this information to my knowledge other than when we see things like TR1 notifications, or open short positions which are reported to the regulator via different methods. Ironically, the reasons for all this uncertainty with the direction of trades is part of mifid II regulations ( trade reporting and transaction reporting) that were brought in back in 2018 to make this more 'transparent'.

data.author: Gorblimey
data.content: Https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/lithium Lithium carbonate futures surged past [resistance] CNY 170,000 per tonne in January, gaining nearly 30% since the start of the year to a two-year high, as signs of strong demand for power storage coincided with the outlook of capped supply. Chinese authorities lowered export rebates for battery producers from April, driving manufacturers to front-run lithium orders. In the meantime, ambitious bets in power and datacenter infrastructure by the Chinese government was combined with the announcement of higher power storage spending, supporting the outlook for lithium and other battery metals. This was combined with Beijing stating it would double EV charging capacity to 180 gigawatts by 2027, supporting lithium-rich energy storage systems. Meanwhile, authorities stated 27 mining permits were cancelled in the lithium hub of Jiangxi, aligned with the earlier suspension of activity in CATL's Jianxiawo lithium mine amid Beijing's anti-involution campaign.

data.author: Gorblimey
data.content: Https://www.mining.com/us-proposed-secure-act-aims-to-offset-chinas-grip-on-critical-minerals/ US lawmakers last week introduced bipartisan legislation to create a new authority for a $2.5 billion critical minerals stockpile, aiming to counter China’s dominance of global supply chains. The proposed Securing Essential and Critical US Resources and Elements (SECURE) Minerals Act would establish a Strategic Resilience Reserve (SRR) to support domestic production and processing of minerals vital to electrification, clean energy and national defense. China currently controls over 60% of the world’s mined rare earths and about 90% of their processing. The Asian nation also holds a major share of the refined production of lithium, graphite and cobalt, all minerals key to electrification, clean energy and national defense. For lithium, China has created a huge glut that has driven down prices globally, rendering many projects in the West unprofitable. In the rare earth sector, it deployed export curbs that have also resulted in high prices. US Senators Jeanne Shaheen (D-NH) and Todd Young (R-IN), alongside Representatives Rob Wittman (R-VA-01) and John Moolenaar (R-MI-02), introduced new legislation to support domestic supply chains to meet national and economic security needs through the creation of a new SRR. The legislation has been introduced on a bicameral and bipartisan basis, reflecting early alignment across chambers and parties. Critical minerals have emerged as a key chokepoint in the global economy, the lawmakers said. The SECURE Act would establish the SRR in an independent government corporation, run by a seven-member board appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate. “China’s global dominance of critical minerals supply chains gives it significant leverage and leaves the US vulnerable to economic coercion. This bipartisan legislation is a historic investment in making the US economy more resilient and supporting good-paying jobs in key sectors like aerospace, autos and technology,” Senator Shaheen said in a news release. “Delivering much-needed stability to the market, providing targeted investments and stockpiling key inputs will help insulate the US from foreign threats and will provide a significant, and cost effective, boost to the US economy.” Path to law Sahar Hafeez, senior counsel, international trade and national security matters at Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman’s Washington DC office told MINING.COM such legislation takes time and will involve subsequent edits and versions on the path to being passed into law. “We understand that the House Committee on Natural Resources is looking to schedule a mark-up and that the Senate is aiming for including this as part of the NDAA (US National Defense Authorization Act),” Hafeez said in an email. The bill establishes new statutory authority to create a $2.5 billion strategic reserve, rather than relying on pre-existing
